abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Poverty Reduction Strategy
            Grant Project (PRSG-4) for Rwanda continues to support the
            Government of Rwanda (GoR) as it implements the next steps
            in its reform program to support growth, now being
            undertaken in the context of enhanced decentralization
            reforms. Within this context, the PRSG-4 is expected to help
            the GoR to : 1) maintain a stable macroeconomic framework,
            put in place reforms to ease the human capital and
            infrastructure constraints to growth, with the aim of
            creating a strong basis for private sector-led economic
            growth, driven by agricultural transformation, promotion of
            exports, deepening of the financial sector, and the use o f
            information communications technology; 2) strengthen further
            the linkages between strategic planning and the Medium-Term
            Expenditure Framework (MTEF), by broadening the focus on
            service delivery to include more strongly the agriculture,
            transport, and financial sectors, while continuing to
            maintain and deepen the progress made in the education,
            health, water, and energy sectors; and 3) continue improving
            governance and transparency through capacity support to
            enable implementation of completed reforms to financial
            management, and the budget and procurement frameworks, with
            a particular emphasis on strengthening the process of fiscal
            decentralization. Expected benefits are as follows: 1) in
            creased access to infrastructure services while continuing
            to consolidate and improve access to education and health
            services to increase the supply of skilled labor in the
            workforce; 2) improved efficiency of spending by supporting
            reforms to strengthen the MTEF and public procurement
            process; 3) strengthened capacity to implement through
            support to civil service reforms to improve ministerial
            structures and provide incentives to staff, increase skills
            of the civil service and reduce turn-over.
